Chitosan capped copper oxide/copper nanoparticles encapsulated microbial resistant nanocomposite films
Tippabattini Jayaramudu a,⁎, Kokkarachedu Varaprasad b, Radha D. Pyarasani c, K. Koteshwara Reddy a, Kanderi Dileep Kumar d, A. Akbari-Fakhrabadi e, R.V. Article history: Received 21 December 2018 Received in revised form 25 January 2019 Accepted 25 January 2019 Available online 27 January 2019
Chitosan (CH) capped inorganic nanomaterials have been considered as significant antibacterial materials in the clinical field. This work shows the synthesis of two new different antibacterial composite films as a result of the incorporation of CH capped copper oxide (CHCuO) and copper (CHCu) nanoparticles (NPs). Here, CHCuO and CHCu NPs were achieved by a facile chemical reduction of Cu2+ ions using sodium hydroxide and ascorbic acid. TEM analysis revealed the morphology as rod-type nanoflakes for CHCuO and a spherical shape for CHCu NPs with ~7 ± 2 nm size. Antimicrobial activity of the developed materials was studied by the inhibition zone method, against both gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria. The antimicrobial activity revealed that the CHCuO NPs and CHCuO-CH film showed a higher inhibition zone than the other nanomaterials. The results suggested that the synthesized materials can be used in wound dressing applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In current decades, the development of cost-effective antibacterial nanoparticles (NPs) and their derivative nanocomposites have gained significant attention for several industrial applications, particularly in biomedical, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, drug delivery and antimicrobial applications [1,2]. NPs have notable physical, chemical, and advanced medical features as well as high potential use in many fields including healthcare application. Nanotechnology is considered as a major integral part in the present ongoing research of the NPs synthesis. Currently, various synthesis techniques have been reported, which include UV irradiation reduction [3], laser ablation [4], microwave processing [5], thermal decomposition [6], electrolysis [7], ion implantation [8,9] and chemical reduction methods [10]. In addition, polymers have been playing a pivotal role in the synthesis and stabilization to acquire the desired shape and size of the metal NPs [11–14]. Among various polymers, biopolymer-stabilized metal NPs have gained significant importance
du@gmail.com (T. Jayaramudu),
in medical applications due to their unique functional properties such as biocompatibility and eco-friendly nature [15,16].
Inclusion of metal NPs into the biopolymers can change properties of the base materials [13]. Moreover, biopolymer-stabilized NPs are opening up a new era of research due to high aspect ratio, low densities and multifunctional characteristics, which makes them suitable for advanced applications especially in antimicrobial and wound dressing [17,18]. Biopolymers not only minimize the production cost of NPs and also control the morphology of NPs [19,20]. Among the existing metals and biopolymers, copper (Cu) and chitosan biological macromolecule (CH) have been selected for the synthesis of NPs for advanced antibacterial applications in biomedicine. CH is a biopolymer composed of β-(1 → 4)-2-amino2-deoxy-D-glucopyranose and it is a natural cationic biopolymer obtained from deacetylation of chitin by a thermochemical reaction [21]. CH has excellent properties such as film-forming ability, good adhesion, nontoxicity and biocompatibility [22–25].
CH has hydroxyl and amino functional groups in their chemical structure. These groups are playing a vital role in the usage of CH in various applications such as biomedical, drug delivery, antimicrobial, wastewater treatment, ion-exchange and functional matrixes for industries [26,27]. Principally, CH has a reducing capacity and significant bacteriostatic/bactericidal property aswell [28,29]. Due to these properties,
CH has been widely used as a dressing material on wounds and burns. CH stabilized Cu-based materials have been principally considered as active antimicrobial agents. This is attributed to the formation of an internal coordination bond between the Cu and CH functional groups. There are many literature reports on the synthesis of CH-based CuO or Cu NPs and studied these materials towards antimicrobial and other technological applications [30–36]. According to the literature, chemical reduction method is a facile process for the synthesis of NPs using biopolymeric materials [37–42] in achieving a better substantial bacteriostatic/bactericidal property. CH mediated flowery-CuO NPs have been reported by an in situ method using ammonia solution via a microwave-induced method and suggested that a low concentration of CH is suitable to formulate oxide metal NPs since the high concentration of CH formed precipitation in the presence of basic media [43]. In another report, copper oxide based chitosan nanocomposite hydrogel beads have been prepared from in situ methods which displayed excellent antimicrobial activity against both gram-positive and gramnegative bacteria [37]. Chitosan-Cu NPs were synthesized via a green chemical process which were further used in emulsion paints to coat the surface of wood and mild steel panels to inhibit the growth of the algae [44]. However, the nanocomposite films of CH capped CuO/Cu NPs and their derivatives were not yet reported in the literature.
In this investigation, two different kinds of microbial resistant CH capped CuO-chitosan (CHCuO-CH) and CH capped Cu-chitosan (CHCu-CH) nanocomposite films were prepared via a solution casting technique. Here, CH capped CuO and Cu NPs were synthesized by a facile chemical reduction using sodium hydroxide and ascorbic acid as nucleation agents. These nanomaterials were characterized with ATRFTIR, UV–vis, XRD and their antimicrobial activity was studied against E. coli and Bacillus.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Chitosan (CH) (DD: 75–85%) of mediummolecular weight with a Brookfield viscosity of 200–800 cP (CAS 9012-76-4) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich chemicals (Chile, South America). Copper sulfate pentahydrate (CuSO4·5H2O), acetic acid (AA), L-ascorbic acid, glutaraldehyde, and sodium hydroxide were purchased from Merck chemicals (Chile, South America). All chemicals were used without further purification. Double distilled water was used throughout the experimentation.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of CHCuO and CHCuO NPs
sections.text:
Initially, a stock solution of CH-acetic acid was prepared by dissolving 1.5 g of CH in a 100 mL of 1.5% (v/v) acetic acid-double distilled water at 60 °C. Then, 5.0 g of CuSO4·5H2O was dissolved in 100 mL of double distilled water in a 250 mL round bottom flask. To this solution, 20 g of CH stock solution was added slowly under constant stirring using a magnetic stirrer with 300 rpm over a period of 30 min. After forming the homogeneous mixture, the reaction temperature was increased to 85 °C with continuous stirring for 45 min. After that, the solution pH was adjusted to ~9 by the gradual addition of sodium hydroxide (0.625M) and the solution color changed to dark blue colloidal, at this moment 20 mL of 0.4258 M ascorbic acid solution was added slowly [44]. Then, the solution color changed to yellow beforefinally becoming red. The stirringwas continued for another 30min. The solution was cooled and washed repeatedly with double distilled water and centrifuged at 8000 rpm, dried in a vacuum oven. A similar procedure was used for the preparation of CHCuO NPs but without using the ascorbic acid. Fig. 1 shows the schematic preparation and formation of the CHCuO and CHCu NPs. Finally, the prepared CHCuO and CHCu NPs were stored in vacuum desiccators until to be used.
2.3. Preparation of CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH films
A simple solvent evaporation process was used to prepare chitosanbased nanocomposites. In this process, 20 mg of both CHCuO and CHCu NPs were re-dispersed in 5 mL of 1.5% v/v aq. acetic acid. Then, a solution of 0.6 g CH in 40 mL of 1.5% aq. acetic acid was added to the above solution and the stirring was continued using a magnetic stirrer with 300 rpm over a period of 12 h. To this solution, a 0.3 mL of 2% aqueous glutaraldehyde solution was added and the stirring was continued another 30 min, then poured into a Petri dish and kept in an oven at 35 °C. For comparison purposes, the pure CH film was prepared by following the above procedure. The developed nanocomposite films were named as the pure CH, CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH nanocomposite films, respectively. The dried films were peeled off from the Petri dish plate and dried in a vacuum oven at 35 °C for 48 h before characterizations.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. ATR-FTIR and UV–vis analysis
sections.text: ATR-FTIR spectra of pure CH, CHCuO NPs, CHCu NPs and their nanocomposite films were studied by using the Perkin Elmer, UATR two (Beaconsfield, Bucks, UK) in the wavelength range of 4000–400 cm−1 with 16 average scans. UV–vis spectrophotometer (HP8452A, Agilent, USA) was used for the confirmation of the prepared CHCuO and CHCu NPs in the range of 250 to 800 nm.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. XRD analysis
sections.text: The crystalline structure of the CHCuO and CHCu NPs was analyzed with Rigaku X-ray diffraction (Cu Kα radiation, with a wavelength of λ 50.1546 nm) at 15 kV and 50 mA and the spectra of 2θ (Bragg angle) range from 5° to 80°.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. TGA analysis
sections.text: Thermal stability of the samples were studied with a TGA Q 50 thermal analyzer (TA Instruments–Waters, LLC, Newcastle, DE) in the temperature range of 25–600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a constant nitrogen flow (100 mL/min).

sections.heading: 2.4.4. Surface morphology, elemental analysis and TEM analysis
sections.text: The surface morphology of CHCuO, CHCu NPs and nanocomposite films (CH, CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH films) were studied with FESEM/EDS (energy dispersive spectroscopy) analysis by using a JEOL JEM-7500F instrument (Tokyo, Japan), scanned at an accelerating voltage 10 kV and the samples were gold-coated before the SEM analysis. The size of CHCuO and CHCu NPs were confirmed from TEM (JEM-1200EX, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) analysis. TEM samples were prepared by dropping two to three drops of a finely dispersed CHCuO and CHCu NP solution (1 mg/1 mL) on a 3 mm copper grid and dried at ambient temperature by removing the excess solution with a fine filter paper.

sections.heading: 2.4.5. Swelling ratio studies
sections.text:
The percent of swelling ratio (Sg/g) behavior was studied by the gravimetrical analysis [45]. The prepared CH, CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH nanocomposite filmswere cut into rectangles with equal weights at approximately ~40 ± 5 mg and dried in a vacuum oven overnight [46]. Then, the filmswere immersed in a beaker containing 50mL of distilled water and allowed to swell, before swelling theweight of the driedfilms were noted. The swelled film weights were noted at certain time intervals and finally, the percent of swelling ratio was calculated using the below Eq. (1):
Swelling ratio Sg=g ¼ Wt−Wd

where,Wt andWd denote theweight of the swollenfilm at specific time equilibrium intervals and the weight of the dry film, respectively. The data provided is an average value of three individual sample readings.

sections.heading: 2.4.6. Antibacterial activity studies
sections.text: Antibacterial activity of the CHCuO, CHCu NPs and nanocomposite films (CH, CHCuO-CH, and CHCu-CH) were performed by the zone inhibitionmethod using gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. The test was performed by using amodified agar disc test method for 48 h in the incubation temperature maintained at 37 °C. The nutrient agar medium was prepared by mixing 5.0 g of peptone, 3.0 g of beef extract and 5.0 g of sodium chloride in a 1000mL distilledwater [13]. Then, 15.0 g of agar was added to the above solution. Before adding agar, the solution pH was adjusted to 7.0 using the digital pH meter, and the agar medium was sterilized in a conical flask at a pressure of 6.8 kg (15 lbs) for 30 min. This medium was transferred into sterilized Petri dishes in a laminar airflow chamber. After solidification, a known amount (50 μL) of the bacteria culture (gram-positive and gram-negative) was spread on the solid surface of themedia. Then, circularly shapedWattman filter paperwas dipped in CHCuO and CHCu (20mg/20mL) NP solutions, and the plates were incubated for 48 h at 37 °C.

sections.heading: 3.1. ATR-FTIR analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the ATR-FTIR spectra of pure CH, CHCuO, CHCu NPs and nanocomposite films which reveal the nature of the functional groups
and elucidates the interaction between CH and CuO/Cu NPs. From Fig. 2A, the pure CH shows a broad characteristic peak at 3324 cm−1 related to the stretching vibration of -OH and -NH groups. The peaks at 2921 and 2871 cm−1 correspond to symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of –CH3, respectively. The peaks at 1636 and 1555 cm−1 correspond to the carbonyl stretching of the secondary amide and bending vibration of the -NH groups. The peaks between 1377, 1420 and 1000–1200 cm−1 were associated to the stretching vibrations of the polysaccharides chain (-C-N- and -C-O-) functional groups [43,47]. However, the CH characteristic peak wavenumbers were shifted after the formation of CHCuO and CHCu NPs. For example, the CHCuO shows a broad peak at 3334 cm−1 and CHCu shows a peak at 3433 cm−1. Similarly, the other CH characteristic peak wavenumbers were also shifted, and these results specify that the CH was wellcapped to the CuO and Cu NPs. Fig. 2B shows the FTIR spectra of CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH nanocomposite films. From Fig. 2B, the CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH nanocomposite films show a sharp and broad -OH stretching vibration peaks at 3250 and 3243 cm−1; these peaks were slightly shifted in their wavenumber when compared with pure CH film (3324 cm−1) as well as their CHCuO and CHCu. These are attributed to the coordination bond formation between the CH capped CHCuO and CHCu and CH.

sections.heading: 3.2. UV–vis analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 3A andB show the absorption spectrumof CHCuO andCHCuNPs which were synthesized by a facile reduction using sodium hydroxide (at pH 9) and ascorbic acid as reducing agents, respectively. In general,
nanosized metal particles have unique features under electromagnetic radiation. Especially, in the UV–visible range, the NPs prepared have absorbed the electromagnetic waves via mutual fluctuation transfer electrons at the surface and showed their corresponding absorbance peak as a function of wavelength. From Fig. 3A CHCuO NPs display an absorption peak at ∼289 nm [48]. These results reveal that the CHCuONPs were successfully formed by the use of NaOH as a
reducing agent. Furthermore, by the addition of the ascorbic acid to the above reaction, the oxidation reaction was hindered, and the absorption band disappeared (∼289 nm). The increased intensity at ∼575 nm (Fig. 3B) [49], which is attributed to the band-to-band transition, indicated the presence of Cu NPs. According to previous literature, the pure copper nanoparticles have been shown maximum absorbance at ∼570 nm [50]. Moreover, a few research reports
C) XRD spectra of i). CH, ii) CHCuO NPs and iii) CHCu NPs.
revealed that ascorbic acid exhibited reducing capacity as well as antioxidant capacity during the formation of copper nanoparticles [51,52].

sections.heading: 3.3. X-ray diffraction analysis
sections.text: Fig. 3C shows the crystallographic structure of CHCuO and CHCuNPs and pure CH. From Fig. 3C, i) the pure CH shows a well-defined broad characteristic peak at 2θ = 19.99, which suggests that a high degree of crystallinity, while the broad peak designates the amorphous nature [53,54]. The CHCuO NPs (ii) show diffraction characteristic peaks at 2θ = 32.67, 35.99, 38.99, 48.94, 52.90 and 61.67° along with a slightly shifted pure CH peak (19.27°). These peaks correspond to the characteristic reflection of (110), (110), (111), (202), (020) and (110) lattice planes and clearly displayed the monoclinic phase of CuO (tenorite, JCPDS 089-2529). Hence, these results are in good agreement with the previous literature [43]. However, the CHCu NPs (iii) show diffraction characteristic peaks at 2θ = 43.47, 50.71 and 74.33° corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes representing the face centered cubic structure of copper (JCPDSNo. 85-1326) [55]. In the same way, the CH peak (20.50°) was observed and was shown in the inset (Fig. 3C iii). But the CH peak was not visible along with characteristic peaks of Cu NPs. It was due to the low intensity of CH and this peak was dominated by characteristic peaks of Cu NPs in the XRD. The developed materials were found to be pure, without any impurities such as Cu(OH)2 and Cu2O peaks not appearing in the CHCuO XRD spectra (Fig. 3C ii). Similarly, the CuO, Cu2O, Cu(OH)2 etc. peaks did not appear in the CHCu XRD spectra (Fig. 3C iii).

sections.heading: 3.4. Thermal analysis
sections.text:
Thermal stability of the synthesized CHCuO and CHCu NPs was measured by using a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) instrument and compared with that of pure CH. From Fig. 4, the weight loss curve shows similar degradation stages with different weight residues. Pure CH displays a steady weight loss between 35 and 158 °C, which is due to the presence of adsorbed water moisture and a sudden degradation between 255 and 377 °C due to the degradation of side pendent groups. Overall, the leftover weight residue of pure CH at 600 °C is 35.12%.
Similarly, the CHCuO and CHCu NPs exhibit the leftover weight residues as 71.8 and 99.3% at the above particular temperature.
Fig. 4. TGA of Pure CH, CHCuO NPs, CHCu NPs, CHCuO-CH n
CHCu possessed higher thermal stability than the pure CH and CHCuO NPs because the Cu NPs degraded via oxidation of Cu to Cu2O and Cu2O to CuO [56]. A similar trend was observed in their composite films such as CHCuO-CH film (38.52%) and CHCu-CH film (42.98%).
The percentage of CuO/Cu NPs in CHCuO and CHCu was calculated from the TGA data. The leftover weight residues of CHCuO and CHCu comprise two parts; the first one is pure CH (35.12%) and second one is CuO/Cu. However, the presence of CH does not affect the thermal decomposition of CuO/Cu NPs. The calculated percentage of CuO and Cu was found as 56.21% and 98.92%, respectively, using the following equation [43].
Wi−Wxð Þ 35:12%þWx ¼ W f :
where, Wi, Wf are the initial and final weights of the CH-CuO, and Wx is the weight of CuO/Cu NPs. These TGA results confirm that the CHCu NPs have higher thermal stability than pure CH and CHCuO.

sections.heading: 3.5. Surface morphology, elemental and TEM analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 5 shows the SEM images of CHCuO, CHCu NPs and their nanocomposite films. The morphology of CHCuO NPs shows nanoflakes with irregular shape and size (Fig. 5A). Recently, Monika et al. reported a similar type of structure, and they concluded that the structure of nanoflakes critically depends on the reaction temperature during the synthesis [31]. Whereas, the CHCu NPs show a spherical structure (Fig. 5B). The pure CH-film shows smooth surface morphology (Fig. 5C). However, the smooth surface morphology was converted to a rough surface with the incorporation of CHCuO NPs into the CH (Fig. 5D). CHCu-CH film shows much rougher surface morphology than that of CHCuO-CH film (Fig. 5E).
Elemental analysis of all these compounds was carried out with the energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) as shown in Fig. 5AI–EI. The EDS spectrum of the CHCuO nanoflakes (Fig. 5AI) conveyed that the synthesized material was mostly comprised of Cu and O.
Fig. 6 shows TEM images and SAED pattern of the synthesized CHCuO and CHCu NPs, which reveals their nanostructural morphology. CHCuO NPs (Fig. 6A) show rod-type nanoflakes, whereas CHCu NPs show spherical morphology with a diameter of ∼7 ± 2 nm, which is consistent with the SEM analysis results. Fig. 6AI and BI shows SAED
anocomposite film and CHCu-CH nanocomposite film.
pattern of their corresponding synthesized nanoparticles (CHCuO and CHCu NPs).

sections.heading: 3.6. Swelling ratio studies
sections.text: The swelling ratio studies are depicted in Fig. 7 which explain the quantity of water adsorbed (at equilibrium) as a function of time. The swelling ratio of pure CH, CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH nanocomposite films increased slowlywith the increasing time. Themaximum swelling capacity was achieved in 5 h and then the values became constant up to 7 h. However, the pure CH film showed a higher swelling trend than that of CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH nanocomposite films. This was due to the enormous crosslinking and tightening between the polymeric chains, which led to the rigid structure and avoided the penetration of water molecules. In addition, the swelling behavior depends on other factors such as the content of filler, crosslinking and porosity [46]. In this investigation, the swelling ratio capacity of the nanocomposite filmswas decreased by the formation of the coordination bond between the functional groups of chitosan and CHCuO/CHCu NPs.

sections.heading: 3.7. Antimicrobial activity
sections.text:
Over the past few decades, various metal NPs such as silver, gold, zinc and copper were investigated towards antimicrobial applications [43,45,57–60]. However, there is no exact mechanism to explain how metal NPs act and kill the bacteria. Nevertheless, a possible mechanism
is reported in the literature considering the formation of pits [61,62]. It was proposed that themetal NPs initially attach to the cellwall and then they damage the membrane of the bacteria cell wall, which causes the formation of pits. Subsequently, the formed pits inhibit the growth of the bacteria. Among such nanomaterials, copper-based metal NPs have gained much attention in antimicrobial applications [62–64]. Fig. 8 shows the antimicrobial activity of synthesized CHCuO, CHCu and nanocomposite films (CH, CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH) against two bacteria such as gram-negative and gram-positive. Inhibition efficiency of these nanomaterials was calculated via the formation of the inhibition zone after 48 h at 37 °C. The whole experiment was carried out in the incubation chamber. Fig. 8A shows the antimicrobial activity against E. coli bacteria with the inhibition zone values of 1.6 cm for CHCuo, 1.4 cm for CHCu, 1.0 cm for CHCuO-CH nanocomposite film and 0.6 cm for CHCu-CH nanocomposite film. Fig. 8B shows the antimicrobial activity against the Bacillus, and their inhibition zone values are 1.3 cm for CHCuo, 0.9 cm for CHCu, 0.75 cm for CHCuO-CH nanocomposite film and 0.5 cm for CHCu-CH nanocomposite film. These results concluded that the CHCuO NPs possessed higher inhibition zone values compared to the CHCu NPs. In addition to that, inhibition efficiency of these NPs was better against E. coli bacteria compared to Bacillus. Similar results were observed with the fabricated nanocomposite films. These results are in good agreement with the earlier research reports, which confirm that CuO NPs have much better antimicrobial activity than the Cu NPs [43,65]. A similar trend in results was observed in the case of nanocomposite films. From the results, we can conclude
that the nanocomposite films showed higher inhibition capacity on gram-negative bacteria. The inhibition capacity may depend on the cell wall surface of bacteria as well as the functionality of nanocomposites (size, shape, cationic and anionic). The developed chitosan-based cationic nanocomposite films have active oxygen- and nitrogen-based functional groups. In addition, the films have reactive oxygen species derived fromCHCuO. It waswell proven in the literature that chitosan derivatives have been significantly inhibiting the grampositive bacterias [66].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The present investigation explains a simple and low-cost synthesis of CuO and Cu NPs from copper sulfate with chitosan biological macromolecule (CH) as a capped material via the chemical reduction. Corresponding nanocomposite films (CHCuO-CH and CHCu-CH) were successfully developed via the solution casting method. CHCuO
NPs were prepared by using sodium hydroxide at pH 9, which were then converted to CHCu NPs using ascorbic acid as a reducing agent at 85 °C by step reduction. The developed nanomaterials were systematically characterized using ATR-FTIR, UV–Vis and XRD. The XRD data confirmed that the synthesized materials did not have any side products. Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that CHCu NPs had higher thermal stability than the CHCuO NPs.
Furthermore, the percentage of CuO and Cu was found as 56.21% and 98.92%, respectively. The surface morphology, elemental analysis and particle sizes were studied using SEM-EDS and TEM. TEM studies revealed that the formed CHCuO NPs had nanoflakes and CHCu NPs had spherical structure. The synthesized nanomaterial showed excellent antimicrobial activity against E. coli and Bacillus. CHCuO NPs and the corresponding nanocomposite (CHCuO-CH) film showed stronger antimicrobial activity compared to the CHCu NPs and their nanocomposite (CHCu-CH) films. Based on these results, the synthesized CuO/Cu NPs and nanocomposites could be used for antimicrobial applications.
